content.description: Sit Start the problem at the slopey ledge at tip of the bulge just left of the corner of the arete. Feet will be underneath the bulge. Pull up and out left to a small crimp rail. Find a small slopey "upside down" pocket.   Toss to the slopey top out.
content.location: On the left side of the Arete. It sit starts on the slopy ledge at tip of the bulge just left of the corner of the arete.

content.description:
(the point of this problem is to only use the overhead"diving board slab" to top out on, so this is a fun eliminate). 

  Sit start with your right hand on a sidepull and a left hand on a negative rail. Fire up to a left hand in-cut rail above. Match the rail or opt for the crimp beside the rail.   Dyno to the right side of the overhang.   Match the lip, heel hook one side and then search for the good crimp on top.   Top out.
content.location: Start to the far right of the inverted side of the boulder under the overhanging slab on top.

content.description: Sit start on the large vertical ledge for your left hand (pinching the top) and a smaller ledge for your right.   Lock off to an in-cut crimp out left and bump left to a better crimp. Dyno up to the top lip and top-out.
content.location: The middle of the overhanging face, sit starts on a large vertical ledge for your left hand (pinching the top) and a smaller ledge for your right.

content.description: Start with your body to leaning to the right of the arete, hands on the bottom ledge. Reach to the good, slopey ledge above and match, then make a biggish toss to the slopey top. Find the pin-hole and use it to your advantage to top out.
content.location: This follows the arete up to a top out on the right.

content.description: To the left of "Wiseman" sit start on a low slopy rail, feet under the bulge. Reach up to another slopey rail above and match. Toss again up to the top, finding the least slopey spots for your hands.
content.location: to the left of "Wiseman" sit starting on a low slopy rail. feet under the bulge.

content.description: This Boulder has two good sides, one with a low overhang to press over leading to a long sloper filled slab, and the other is an angular incline with a large "diving board" slab sticking out overhead.
